    "data": {
        "quiz": {
            "_id": "68aaa818fcacfd6c1ca381aa",
            "title": "Java Programming Quiz",
            "description": "AI-generated Java quiz",
            "metadata": {
                "grade": 8,
                "subject": "Java",
                "totalQuestions": 10,
                "timeLimit": 20,
                "difficulty": "mixed",
                "tags": [
                    "java",
                    "programming"
                ]
            },
            "questions": [
                {
                    "questionId": "q1",
                    "questionText": "What is the purpose of the 'public static void main' method in Java?",
                    "questionType": "mcq",
                    "options": [
                        "To declare a variable",
                        "To define a class",
                        "To start the execution of a Java program",
                        "To import a package"
                    ],
                    "correctAnswer": "To start the execution of a Java program",
                    "explanation": "The main method is the entry point of a Java program.",
                    "difficulty": "easy",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "Java Basics"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q2",
                    "questionText": "Is Java a case-sensitive language?",
                    "questionType": "true_false",
                    "correctAnswer": "true",
                    "explanation": "Java is case-sensitive, meaning that uppercase and lowercase letters are treated differently.",
                    "difficulty": "easy",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "Java Basics"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q3",
                    "questionText": "What is the difference between '==' and '.equals()' in Java?",
                    "questionType": "short_answer",
                    "correctAnswer": "The '==' operator checks for reference equality, while the '.equals()' method checks for content equality.",
                    "explanation": "The '==' operator checks if both objects point to the same memory location, while the '.equals()' method checks if the contents of the objects are equal.",
                    "difficulty": "medium",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "Java Basics"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q4",
                    "questionText": "What is inheritance in Java?",
                    "questionType": "mcq",
                    "options": [
                        "A process of creating a new class from an existing class",
                        "A process of creating a new object from an existing object",
                        "A process of creating a new package from an existing package",
                        "A process of creating a new interface from an existing interface"
                    ],
                    "correctAnswer": "A process of creating a new class from an existing class",
                    "explanation": "Inheritance allows a new class to inherit the properties and behavior of an existing class.",
                    "difficulty": "medium",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "OOP"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q5",
                    "questionText": "Is it possible to override a static method in Java?",
                    "questionType": "true_false",
                    "correctAnswer": "false",
                    "explanation": "Static methods cannot be overridden in Java.",
                    "difficulty": "medium",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "OOP"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q6",
                    "questionText": "What is polymorphism in Java?",
                    "questionType": "short_answer",
                    "correctAnswer": "The ability of an object to take on multiple forms.",
                    "explanation": "Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass.",
                    "difficulty": "medium",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "OOP"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q7",
                    "questionText": "What is the purpose of the 'throws' clause in Java?",
                    "questionType": "mcq",
                    "options": [
                        "To declare a variable",
                        "To define a method",
                        "To specify the exceptions that a method may throw",
                        "To import a package"
                    ],
                    "correctAnswer": "To specify the exceptions that a method may throw",
                    "explanation": "The 'throws' clause is used to declare the exceptions that a method may throw.",
                    "difficulty": "hard",
                    "points": 2,
                    "topic": "Java Basics"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q8",
                    "questionText": "Can a subclass constructor call a superclass constructor?",
                    "questionType": "true_false",
                    "correctAnswer": "true",
                    "explanation": "A subclass constructor can call a superclass constructor using the 'super' keyword.",
                    "difficulty": "medium",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "OOP"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q9",
                    "questionText": "What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface in Java?",
                    "questionType": "short_answer",
                    "correctAnswer": "An abstract class can have both abstract and non-abstract methods, while an interface can only have abstract methods.",
                    "explanation": "An abstract class can have both abstract and non-abstract methods, while an interface can only have abstract methods.",
                    "difficulty": "hard",
                    "points": 2,
                    "topic": "OOP"
                },
                {
                    "questionId": "q10",
                    "questionText": "Can a class implement multiple interfaces in Java?",
                    "questionType": "true_false",
                    "correctAnswer": "true",
                    "explanation": "A class can implement multiple interfaces in Java.",
                    "difficulty": "medium",
                    "points": 1,
                    "topic": "OOP"
                }
            ],
            "createdBy": "68a9f2d17a071e1e71ca5966",
            "isPublic": false,
            "isActive": true,
            "version": 1,
            "createdAt": "2025-08-24T05:50:16.620Z",
            "updatedAt": "2025-08-24T05:50:16.620Z",
            "questionsCount": 10,
            "aiGenerated": true,
            "aiModel": "groq"
        }
    }
}
